title: Subtle Anterior STEMI Calculator (4-Variable)
description: Differentiates normal variant ST elevation (benign early repolarization) from anterior STEMI in patients with chest pain and non-diagnostic ECG changes. This sensitive tool helps identify patients with subtle anterior wall MI who may benefit from urgent percutaneous coronary intervention.

parameters.name: qtc_interval
parameters.description: Bazett-corrected QT interval measured on ECG

parameters.name: qrs_amplitude_v2
parameters.description: QRS amplitude (height) in lead V2 measured from baseline to peak of R wave

parameters.name: r_wave_amplitude_v4
parameters.description: R wave amplitude (height) in lead V4 measured from baseline to peak of R wave

parameters.name: st_elevation_v3
parameters.description: ST segment elevation measured 60 ms after the J point in lead V3

result.name: score
result.description: Calculated score for subtle anterior STEMI probability

ranges.interpretation: Score <18.2 suggests benign early repolarization rather than acute coronary occlusion. Clinical correlation and serial ECGs recommended if symptoms persist.
Score ≥18.2 indicates likely anterior STEMI with probable LAD occlusion. Consider urgent cardiology consultation and cardiac catheterization. Sensitivity 83.3%, specificity 87.7%.

references: Driver BE, Khalil A, Henry T, Kazmi F, Adil A, Smith SW. A new 4-variable formula to differentiate normal variant ST segment elevation in V2-V4 (early repolarization) from subtle left anterior descending coronary occlusion – Adding QRS amplitude of V2 improves the model. J Electrocardiol. 2017 Nov-Dec;50(6):836-843. doi: 10.1016/j.jelectrocard.2017.08.005.

Smith SW, Khalil A, Henry TD, Rosas M, Chang RJ, Hocken C, et al. Electrocardiographic differentiation of early repolarization from subtle anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction. Ann Emerg Med. 2012 Jul;60(1):45-56.e2. doi: 10.1016/j.annemergmed.2012.02.015.
formula: Score = 0.052 × (QTc in ms) - 0.151 × (QRS amplitude V2 in mm) - 0.268 × (R wave amplitude V4 in mm) + 1.062 × (ST elevation V3 in mm)
notes: Only use if ECG shows ≥1 mm ST elevation in ≥1 of leads V2-V4
Exclude if ECG shows non-concave STE, inferior reciprocal changes, anterior ST depression, Q waves in V2-V4, or T wave inversion in V2-V6
QTc should be measured using Bazett's formula: QTc = QT / √RR
ST elevation should be measured 60 ms after the J point, not at the J point itself
This 4-variable version is more sensitive than the original 3-variable formula
Clinical correlation is essential - if STEMI is still suspected despite negative score, proceed with caution and consider serial ECGs
